name: The Family & Youth Institute
mission: Redefining the narrative on Muslim mental health and well-being and championing a world where individuals, families, and communities are empowered and flourishing.
theoryOfChange: The Family & Youth Institute explicitly states 'the fyi's theory of change' within their 'Research' section. Their approach is described as a community-based participatory research model that ensures community voices and experiences drive their research. This involves partnering with communities to pinpoint priorities, exploring research questions, identifying wellness needs, and addressing concerns within faith and cultural contexts. They engage and integrate community voices throughout the research process, incorporate community perspectives on data, identify practical solutions, and share the benefits. Their mission is to strengthen and empower individuals, families, and communities through research and education, working to shift narratives and promote mental health and well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 29/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.

components.evidence: Board governance: baseline (2 members, emerging org)
components.name: Governance

judge_issues.message: The rationale states that the overall score is moderated by low data confidence, but the data confidence is not factored into the amal_score directly. It is an independent metric. The amal_score is a function of alignment, impact, and risk.
The risk deduction is -5 due to the small board size (2 members). This should be explicitly mentioned in the amal_score_rationale.
BBB name 'Ackerman Institute For The Family' may not match 'The Family & Youth Institute' (similarity: 67%)
Jargon detected in baseline narrative: 'asnaf categories'

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

score_details.score_summary: THE FAMILY AND YOUTH INSTITUTE shows good impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied). Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The FYI focuses on mental health research, community education, and aging projects.
The organization reported total revenue of $850,837.
The organization provides various donation options and methods for supporters.
The FYI is Zakat-eligible and maintains a policy for distributing funds according to asnaf categories.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The FYI demonstrates strong financial management and efficient fundraising, though its overall score is moderated by low data confidence and a specialized focus area.
areas_for_improvement: Limited external data confidence and third-party verification scores
Narrower donor alignment profile compared to larger national advocacy groups

dimension_explanations.alignment: The FYI shows medium alignment for Muslim donors by providing Zakat-eligible giving options and addressing urgent community needs like aging and youth development [3][4]. However, its specific focus on research and advocacy may not fit all donor profiles seeking direct service delivery [1].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization operates as a capacity-building entity, utilizing a total revenue of $850,837 to fund community education and mental health research [2]. While it maintains a high program expense ratio of 83.6%, the direct cost per beneficiary is not publicly standardized, leading to a moderate impact score [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening individuals and families through evidence-based mental health and development programs.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.6% ensures the majority of funds directly support research and education
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.09 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity position with 23.6 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: The FYI focuses on positive youth development and community empowerment through specialized initiatives like the Aging with Dignity Project and Mental Health Research [1]. The organization is recognized as Zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations through supported asnaf categories [4].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The FYI demonstrates strong financial management and efficient fundraising, though its overall score is moderated by low data confidence and a specialized focus area.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with a <cite id="11">small board of only 2 members</cite>, which may limit diverse oversight and long-term institutional stability.
There is a <cite id="12">lack of consistent beneficiary data</cite> available, making it difficult to calculate the exact cost-effectiveness of its programs.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization does not currently meet BBB standards due to its small board size and lack of formal review.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization has a long track record and has maintained high financial reserves to mitigate short-term risks.
risk_factors: <cite id="11">Board size of only 2 members</cite> poses a risk to organizational oversight
<cite id="13">Low data confidence score</cite> due to limited transparency
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="11">governance risks</cite> and limited external verification of outcomes.

confidence.notes: Financial efficiency is high, but governance and transparency metrics are weak.

alignment.explanation: The organization offers a <cite id="5">verified Zakat program</cite> and serves an underserved niche in Muslim mental health and advocacy.
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="16">specific Zakat allocation policy</cite> would help donors better understand how their religious taxes are utilized.

credibility.explanation: While the organization has a <cite id="1">long history since 2006</cite>, its credibility is currently hampered by <cite id="13">low data confidence (0.3)</cite> and a lack of third-party transparency seals.
credibility.improvement: The FYI could improve credibility by <cite id="14">expanding its board of directors</cite> and pursuing a Candid Seal of Transparency.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">high program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite> and a clear <cite id="15">documented theory of change</cite> focused on capacity building.
impact.improvement: The charity should <cite id="12">publish annual beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Documented Theory of Change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct implementation of research and education

rich_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening individuals and families through evidence-based mental health and development programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value intellectual and research-based approaches to community empowerment and want to support the mental health infrastructure of the American Muslim community.
donor_motivations: Want to support evidence-based mental health resources
Value research that influences national policy and media
Prefer lean organizations with very low fundraising costs
Seek to fulfill Zakat through educational and advocacy efforts
giving_considerations: The organization is a small-scale research institute rather than a direct service provider
Governance is currently centralized within a very small board
Impact is measured through community empowerment rather than individual aid metrics
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-volume direct humanitarian aid or those who require large, multi-member independent board oversight.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear theory of change and some outcome tracking, but lacks rigorous external evaluations or RCTs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The FYI creates impact by conducting research that informs community education, which in turn strengthens individual and family resilience.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that mental health interventions are culturally appropriate and effective for the target population.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a small research institute with a niche focus, additional funding would allow for the expansion of the Aging with Dignity and Youth Development programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="6">White House recognition</cite> and focus on academic-grade research.
similar_orgs: Institute for Social Policy and Understanding (ISPU)

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focus on clinical research and training
similar_organizations.name: Maristan

strengths.detail: The organization allocates <cite id="4">83.6% of its total expenses</cite> directly to its research and community programs, exceeding industry benchmarks for lean operations.
The FYI maintains <cite id="7">23.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant buffer to sustain long-term research projects despite market fluctuations.
The organization's expertise has been <cite id="6">quoted at the White House</cite>, demonstrating that its research has a high level of credibility and policy relevance.

strengths_deep_dive: The FYI's financial health is characterized by extreme efficiency and low overhead. According to its <cite id="3">2023 financial filings</cite>, the organization raised over $850,000 while spending only <cite id="8">$0.09 to raise every dollar</cite>. This efficiency allows the organization to maximize its <cite id="9">$806,832 in public contributions</cite> for its specialized mental health research. Furthermore, the organization has demonstrated a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 6.1%</cite>, indicating steady growth and the ability to attract consistent community support for its niche mission.
rich_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a specialized research and education organization that has been <cite id="1">operating since 2006</cite> to strengthen the mental health and developmental outcomes of Muslim individuals and families. The organization focuses on bridging the gap between academic research and community needs through initiatives such as the <cite id="2">Aging with Dignity Project and Marriage Support programs</cite>. With a <cite id="3">total revenue of $850,837 in 2023</cite>, The FYI maintains a lean operational structure, directing a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite> toward its core research and community education efforts. The organization is <cite id="5">recognized as Zakat-eligible</cite>, specifically serving the category of fisabilillah (in the path of Allah) by providing mental health resources and educational frameworks that empower the community. Despite its relatively small scale, the organization has achieved significant recognition, with its <cite id="6">research quoted at the White House</cite> and featured in national media outlets. Financially, the charity demonstrates high stability, maintaining <cite id="7">23.6 months of working capital</cite> and a <cite id="8">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring that donor contributions are utilized with minimal overhead leakage.
